body:
### Problem

In Japanese, half-width katakana and voicing mark are displayed in 2 characters wide, and Neovim also showed them as expected too. However, it is not the case with Neovim v0.11.0 and after.

The problem is, terminals show them as two-characters wide. It causes visual corruption in many ways. The following screenshot illustrates how it affects `colorcolumn`.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/eaf40029-89bf-4528-8ceb-8a09688e0922)

In a real-world text file, the wrong display width often causes unexpected soft wrap and results in TUI corruption on every scroll... just unusable.

Note that the screenshots are Neovim on WSL2 on Windows Terminal, but I confirmed that Neovim with iTerm2 on macOS behaves wrongly as well. Also note that the Windows Terminal itself wrongly renders voicing mark (the mark should be right after character), but it's a separate problem.

For reference, this is how VS Code renders them:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0bad52f9-a4ca-4ae1-88cd-048fe9fb8cc8)

In addition, `strdisplaywidth('ｶﾞ')` is `2` on v0.10.4 but `1` on v0.11.0.

---

I checked several versions:

- OK: nvim v0.10.4, vim 0.9.1500
- NG: nvim v0.11.0, v0.11.4, v0.12.0-dev-707+g 807bc00dd6

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a file containing the following contents, namely `halfkana.txt`
  ```
  ｱｲｳｴｵ
  ｶﾞｷﾞｸﾞｹﾞｺﾞ
  ﾊﾟﾋﾟﾌﾟﾍﾟﾎﾟ
  
  
  vim: set colorcolumn=15:
  ```
2. `nvim --clean halfkana.txt`
3. Notice the corruption.
4. `echo strdisplaywidth('ｶﾞ')` and see `1`.

### Expected behavior

- Katakana is shown as in v0.10.4.
- `echo strdisplaywidth('ｶﾞ')` returns `2`.

### Nvim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.11.0

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

No, 0.9.1500

### Operating system/version

Ubuntu 22.04 (WSL 2)

### Terminal name/version

Windows Terminal 1.23.11132.0 & tmux

### $TERM environment variable

screen-256color

### Installation

Linuxbrew

comment_data.body: `git bisect` gives me the first bad commit: cfdf68a7acde16597fbd896674af68c42361102c

I'm not familiar with Unicode, but I think I understand what is happening here.
Sorry if I misused some technical terms of unicode (I'm not sure what code point or grapheme is...)

We are computing widths by following rule:

1. Check the width of the first codepoint and add the width to total width
  https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/cfdf68a7acde16597fbd896674af68c42361102c/src/nvim/plines.c#L474
2. Find the next codepoint.
  https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/cfdf68a7acde16597fbd896674af68c42361102c/src/nvim/plines.c#L475
3. Keep adding the width of successive codepoints until end.

At step 2, the next codepoint is determined by the Grapheme Break Property of Unicode.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/cfdf68a7acde16597fbd896674af68c42361102c/src/nvim/mbyte.c#L1835


In the case of `ｶﾞ`, it consists of [FF76, FF9E]. According to [GraphemeBreakProperty.txt](https://www.unicode.org/Public/UCD/latest/ucd/auxiliary/GraphemeBreakProperty.txt), FF76 is in `Other` class and FF9E is in `Extend` class. [The definition](https://www.unicode.org/Public/16.0.0/ucd/auxiliary/GraphemeBreakTest.html) says that it is not allowed to break between them.

So our calculation results in:

1. Check the first codepoint FF76, and its width `1` is added to total width.
2. Find the next codepoint, but FF76 and FF9E is not allowed to break, so skip the FF9E.
3. There is no codepoint left, returning total width `1`.

The problem is, despite FF76 and FF9E is not breakable in the sense of grapheme crusters, ｶ and ｶﾞ should have the different display width.
As for the strange font rendering on Windows Terminal, there is a issue: https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/issues/18087. Though they are independent issues, an argument there is very similar.

It seems that FF9E is now considered a composing character, while it previously occupies an independent cell after the FF76.

I tested various terminals:
- The bug doesn't happen in kitty, Alacritty or Ghostty.
- It happens in XTerm, WezTerm, Konsole, Terminator, foot, etc..

Meanwhile, with Nvim 0.10.4 the situation is reversed: it happens in the former group of terminals, but not the latter group.

> ｶ and ｶﾞ should have the different display width.

Do they? Does the Unicode specification say anything about this?

> Do the Unicode specification say anything about this?

Unfortunately, I've not found such a sentence...

However, in Japanese, voice mark (and semi voice mark) of half-width katakana usually take a half-width cells in monospace fonts.

Half width katakana is a bit dated letters, but still used on long-lived systems like accounting systems. It is also used in receipt from supermarkets, because you want to write as many letters as possible within limited paper width. Most of them prints those symbols as if they are independent letters.

Width 1 is correct as per current unicode standard for FF76+FF9E. kitty renders it in one cell. While it can be argued that it appears better in two cells, that's not what the current standard says. You can force it to render in two cells by inserting a space in between or using the width part of kitty text sizing protocol:

Attached screenshot shows rendering via text sizing and with space in between

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/eedccdc7-a2ea-4945-a52a-91b594e5fda6)

> Width 1 is correct as per current unicode standard for FF76+FF9E

Could you provide some reference links if possible?
From my own research, I keep finding results that say Unicode specifies character width per codepoint but does not specify character width per grapheme unit. Example: https://github.com/wezterm/wezterm/issues/4223
My understanding is that FF9E (and FF9F) are not combining characters, so it wouldn't be strange to calculate them with independent width. That is, 1+1 for a width of 2. However, this is just my amateur thinking, so if possible, I'd like to know which part of the specification I should refer to.

Yeah previously we have assumed combining marks cannot alter the base width. The only exception added in the big 0.11 rework was support for some variant selectors to force presentation style. We will need to add more cases.

> Width 1 is correct as per current unicode standard 

My understanding is rather that the Unicode standard doesn't unambiguously specify how monospace fonts should cell count extended grapheme clusters exactly. What is happening is rather an ongoing conversation between terminal implementers and TUI app implementers how to reasonably interpret various available Unicode properties and guidelines, which also vary across versions and revisions.

we (vim and neovim) have setcellwidth() to fix ambiguities of base chars, but we might need to extend this mechanism to some common corner cases, such as this one and "enclosed 1" emoji (on phone, too lazy to link the issue)

The Unicode standard doesnt specify anything about how to display
graphemes in cells. Indeed it doesn't say anything about terminal
emulators at all. What it does do is specify how to split up text into
graphemes. It also specifies certain properties for codepoints and
codepoint clusters, that can be used to try to determine how many cells
to display a piece of text in.

I have made the effort to standardise this into a simple to follow and
implement standard, see https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/text-sizing-protocol/#the-algorithm-for-splitting-text-into-cells

But, from history it is quite clear that it is *hopeless* to try to get
as diverse an ecosystem as terminals and terminal programs to agree on
widths and an algorithm for something as complex as all of human text.
Therefore, in that same document I linked to above there is a
comprehensive solution for this issue, namely allowing terminal programs
to tell the terminal in how many cells they want each piece of text
rendered.
https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/text-sizing-protocol/#fixing-the-character-width-issue-for-the-terminal-ecosystem

That is precisely what I demonstrated in my screenshot above.
If nvim used that it could choose whatever width it deemed to be correct
for any grapheme and not care what the terminal thinks is the correct
width.

Now to the question of what the width of this particular pair of code
points should be. There are currently two general purpose (ignoring some
niche ones like regional indicators) mechanisms in the unicode standard
that are used to modify the cell width of a grapheme. The default width
for all graphemes is 1 cell.

The first mechanism is east asian width and the second is
emoji presentation. The latter is not applicable here. The former
potentially is, but as it stands, there is no rule anywhere in
EastAsianWidth.txt that says this combination should be wide
(as far as I know, please correct me if I am wrong).
In the absence of such a rule it has to be 1 cell wide.

I strongly suggest you do not start making up your own rules for how
wide particular graphemes should be. That way lies utter chaos. The
correct solution would be to petition the Unicode consortium to add
extra rules to EastAsianWidth.txt for use in terminals or similar
monospaced contexts.

That is likely to be a lot of effort, probably leading nowhere, so
instead you can also consider using the width part of the text sizing
protocol which will allow you to at least render such things correctly on
supporting terminals which currently are kitty and foot, but I expect
that set will increase with time. As it stands you will always be wrong
in some subset of terminals no matter what you do. With the text sizing
protocol or something like it, at least there is a path to a fully
robust solution to this entire class of issues.

> The Unicode standard doesnt specify anything about how to display
graphemes in cells. Indeed it doesn't say anything about terminal
emulators at all. 

> I strongly suggest you do not start making up your own rules for how
wide particular graphemes should be. 

The thing is that this is exactly what kitty (just like everyone else) is doing, given the lack of a normative standard:p Of course is a very good idea for a new implementation to follow popular existing implementations as a reference (your summary of kitty's is as good as any other, but it is descriptive, not normative. Pre-existing terminals which render ambiwidth chars as double-width are also valid, as an example). 

> there is no rule anywhere in
EastAsianWidth.txt that says this combination should be wide
(as far as I know, please correct me if I am wrong).
In the absence of such a rule it has to be 1 cell wide.

In particular, your last sentence is doing exactly that. The rules are not clear, therefore you made up your _own rule_, just like we all have to. It is not the same as "what the current standard says."

The only normative rule I find in Tr11 (East Asian Width) is "In particular, nonspacing marks do not possess actual advance width."  Stating that **all**  kinds of combining marks now need to behave according to the existing praxis of non-spacing marks is a wild extrapolation of the actual text of the standard, and one that will paint us in a very bad corner moving forward.

> consider using the width part of the text sizing protocol

This is a very good idea and something we will look into, but neovim also wants to support the preexisting terminals where this issue is reported.

On Thu, Jul 03, 2025 at 07:44:32AM -0700, bfredl wrote:
> bfredl left a comment (neovim/neovim#34733)
>
> > The Unicode standard doesnt specify anything about how to display
> graphemes in cells. Indeed it doesn't say anything about terminal
> emulators at all.
>
> > I strongly suggest you do not start making up your own rules for how
> wide particular graphemes should be.
>
> The thing is that this is exactly what kitty (just like everyone else) is doing, given the lack of a normative standard:p Of course is a very good idea for a new implementation to follow popular existing implementations as a reference (your summary of kitty's is as good as any other, but it is descriptive, not normative. Pre-existing terminals which render ambiwidth chars as double-width are also valid, as an example).

It's not descriptive, it is normative. kitty did not comply with that
spec, it had to be altered to comply with it, see the linked issue.
https://github.com/kovidgoyal/kitty/issues/8533
Thus it is *not* a description of kitty's algorithm, but reflects the
simplest set of rules I could come up with based on a survey of
existing practice and the Unicode standard at its latest revision.

Moreover it comes with an actual tool to test terminal compliance that
uses test data from the Unicode consortium for grapheme segmentation in
addition to other corner cases.

If you have some issue with the spec, why not actually address it in the
public discussion for it so everyone can benefit. Otherwise this will be
a perpetual game of whack-a-mole.

>
> > there is no rule anywhere in
> EastAsianWidth.txt that says this combination should be wide
> (as far as I know, please correct me if I am wrong).
> In the absence of such a rule it has to be 1 cell wide.
>
> In particular, your last sentence is doing exactly that. The rules are not clear, therefore you made up your _own rule_, just like we all have to. It is not the same as "what the current standard says."
>
> The only normative rule I find in Tr11 (East Asian Width) is "In particular, nonspacing marks do not possess actual advance width."  Stating that **all**  kinds of combining marks now need to behave according to the existing praxis of non-spacing marks is a wild extrapolation of the actual text of the standard, and one that will paint us in a very bad corner moving forward.

The spec states non-spacing marks do not possess actual advance width.
That is *all* it says on this subject. If there are combining marks you
feel should not behave as non spacing marks, then make the case for
them. As I stated in my spec I am open to revisions to it. Revisions
based on public discussion by people with knowledge of the languages and
scripts involved.

I know of no combining mark that actually should be rendered in a
whole extra cell, aka one that *doubles* the width of the preceding
character. If you do by all means make a case for it. "Existing
practice" is completely undefined since most people in this space
haven't even considered these issues let alone made an informed choice
on them. So existing practice is just whatever corner cases fall through
each individual implementations algorithm.

>
> > consider using the width part of the text sizing protocol
>
> This is a very good idea and something we will look into, but neovim also wants to support the preexisting terminals where this issue is reported.

The only way to do that, is to maintain compatibility tables for every
terminal emulator and terminal emulator version. If that's a path you
wish to follow, by all means, it's your project.

Let me not waste more of your time, if you wish to discuss improving the
spec, by all means feel free to comment at the issue linked above.
Otherwise all the best and sorry for the noise.

First of all, thank you all, I've understood the situation is far more complex than I initially thought. It'll be very difficult to solve this in general case...

One thing I want to mention here is that FF9E is *neither* a combining character *nor* a non-spacing character. This is `Lm` (Letter, Modifier) class.

> FF9E..FF9F     ; H  # Lm     [2] HALFWIDTH KATAKANA VOICED SOUND MARK..HALFWIDTH KATAKANA SEMI-VOICED SOUND MARK

(from https://www.unicode.org/Public/UCD/latest/ucd/EastAsianWidth.txt)

Therefore, FF9E is a very *special* case in a sense that it *is* a grapheme extenders but *is not* a non-spacing combining marks. I also found a sentence which call it a *outlier*.

> Linebreak uses the CM class, which includes all Mc, Mn, and Me characters, plus some others. In order for it to actually  not break default grapheme clusters, it needs to include all of the Grapheme_Extend characters. With all but 2 characters it does. The Grapheme_Extend characters includes Mn, Me, and Other_Grapheme_Extend. The first two are included already in CM. The Other_Grapheme_Extend mostly includes Mc characters, which are also in CM. **The only 2 outliers are:**
>
> FF9E ; Other_Grapheme_Extend # Lm HALFWIDTH KATAKANA VOICED SOUND MARK
> FF9F ; Other_Grapheme_Extend # Lm HALFWIDTH KATAKANA SEMI-VOICED SOUND MARK

(from https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2003/03106-lb6-issue.htm)

The same goes true for FF9F.

Considering that, counting FF76+FF9E as 2 cell wide is very natural for me.

## References

- https://www.unicode.org/Public/UCD/latest/ucd/EastAsianWidth.txt
- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dakuten_and_handakuten
- https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2003/03106-lb6-issue.htm
- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21722729/what-is-the-difference-between-combining-characters-and-grapheme-extenders-i

> Therefore, FF9E is a very special case in a sense that it is a grapheme extenders but is not a non-spacing combining marks.

Utf8proc has some ideas about what categories of chars should have width 1 or 0 even when used as "Extend". I will try to figure out if it something which makes sense in general for us to use, but at least it gives width 1 for these half-width kana signs and 0 for non-spacing marks.
